--I have appointed S. Blum my agent to conduce the business of a Dry Goods merchant in the city of Richmond, on Broad street, with authority to buy and sail for cash only.
C. N. Josephson.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 20, Number 13, page 2.

div3.head: War matters.
div3.p:
By reference to our telegraph column, it will be seen that a reverse has occurred to Col. Pegram's command in Gen. Garnett's decision, near Laurel Hill.
Passengers by the Central train, yesterday, were of the opinion that the news is authentic.
Nevertheless, the Lynchburg papers of yesterday report direct intelligence from Laurel Hill, to the effect that the Yankees were routed with heavy loss.
We can, therefore, only refer the reader to the news columns, and let every one draw his own inference of the truth of what is there reported.
Our own correspondent's letters are to the 9th inst., (Tuesday,) up to which time all was going on prosperously for the Southern cause.

On Thursday last, a detachment of our cavalry were reconnoitering on the Warwick road, six miles from Newport News, at a place called Lee's Store.
They discovered a party of the enemy, and forthwith attacked them killing four and taking a number of prisoners.
One was shot in a tree, and the way he came to terra frima is said to have outstripped all previous ideas of speed.
The killed and captured are said to be Germans.
The only damage sustained by our cavalry was the loss of one horse, owned by Mr Wilcox, of the Charles City Troop.
The enemy would doubtless have been all captured, but for the fact that they were smart enough to retreat to a newly ploughed field, where the horses of the Cavalry could not successfully pursue them.
This account is brought by gentlemen just from the Peninsula, and is authentic.
The Newbern (N. C.) Progress, of Friday last, has the following:

q.p:
Information reached here late last night by a Lieutenant of the Roanoke Guards, from the undersigned, that on Wednesday, 10th inst., between 12 and 1 o'clock, a man-of-war, 44 guns, came under the guns at Fort Hatteras, when an engagement took place, which lasted three-fourths of an hour, each party firing about 7 or 8 guns.
No damage was done on our side.
The vessel was struck twice and thought to have been disabled, as she struck colors and sloped.
Lieutenant C. W. Night,
Commander at Fort Hatteras.

div3.p:
We have nothing of interest from Manassas Junction or the neighborhood of Alexandria.
The latest from Gen. Johnston's column is that he had been largely reinforced, and circumstances led to the belief that an advance movement was contemplated.
The Lynchburg Republican has the following:

q.p:
"On Wednesday last a skirmish occurred near Bunker Hill, twelve miles from Winchester, between a company of our cavalry and the enemy, in which two of the latter were killed and there taken prisoners.
No one injured on our side.
The prisoners were brought into Winchester on Thursday morning."

It is confirmed that three Pennsylvania regiments of Patterson's command, have returned home.
The story that they were fired upon by their own troops, in consequence of their stampede, is probably unfounded.

It will be seen by a proclamation which we publish this morning, that the militia in all the counties North of James River, and East of the Blue Ridge, as well as all in the Valley of the State North of James River, are called into immediate service.
We presume that many of our young men will hasten to attach themselves to volunteer companies, although there is nothing humiliating in going with the militia.
All things considered, however, we think we should prefer the volunteer service.

div3.p: We copy the following from the Nashville Gazette, of the 12th inst., but do not vouch for its accuracy:

q.p:
"We learn from a gentleman direct from Hickman, Ky., that Gen. Prentiss, with a number of his men; left Cairo on Monday last and made an excursion down the river, some thirty miles. On Tuesday evening, he reached Wolf Island, and effected a landing.
He afterwards left the boat and made a reconnoitering expedition through the country.

"A party of Missourians, numbering upwards of 400, who were stationed at different points on the opposite side of the river, watched his movements, and when he was known to be a reasonable distance from the boat, they crossed the river, surrounded Prentiss and his party, and took them prisoners."

div3.head: The traitors.
div3.p:
With the exception of the Northwest, Virginia has been pretty well purged of traitors.
Here and there they linger in small numbers, keeping very quiet, and waiting with downcast looks and sealed lips an opportunity for vengeance upon good and true men. It is only in the Northwest that they are open, blatant and defiant in their allegiance to the bloody despotism at Washington.
We have heard of deeds of crime committed upon Virginia women by the invaders, to whom these traitors have opened the door of Western Virginia, that make the blood run cold.
One of them, which is alleged upon good authority to have occurred at Phillippi, we dare not narrate till we have the most explicit evidence.--The parallel is not to be found among the outrages of any war in which the United States was ever engaged, and has only its equal in atrocity in a horrible crime and dismal tragedy in Alexandria, which, upon its first publication, was deemed incredible, but which now is supported by the declaration of one of the oldest clergymen in Virginia, whose name, if we felt at liberty to give it, would be the most ample guaranty of the accuracy of any statement which he might make.
If such internal deeds go unpunished, then has vengeance forsaken earth and Justice deserted Heaven.

div3.head: Edward Everett.
div3.p:
In his Fourth of July speech in New York, Edward Everett outherods Herod. He shows himself a more implacable enemy of the South, and a more determined adversary of all compromise, than some of the rankest Abolitionists.
Every word of his late anti-Southern tirade could be answered by extracts from his own speeches of a year ago. But we cannot say that we are disappointed in the man. He is one of a large class of his countrymen, who have brains enough, but no souls.
He has an oratorical tongue, but a deaf and dumb heart.
This man has perambulated the South, eulogizing the Southern Washington, whose work he is now laboring to destroy, and receiving the overflowing hospitality of Southern homes, which he is now laboring to desolate.
That he has no gratitude, no sensibility, no moral courage, is evident enough from his present course.
He has described the character of Washington in strains which have enraptured the nation, yet proved by his actions that he is destitute of every virtue which distinguished the subject of his eulogies.
Another illustration that a gifted mind may be allied to the most contracted, selfish and ignoble Nature.

div3.head: Gen. Wool.
div3.p:
Some of the Northern papers are beginning to grumble because Gen. Wool has been condemned to inaction in Troy.
They do not understand why Gen. Scott has sent the officer next in rank to himself (we believe that is the position occupied by Gen. Wool,) to his quiet home on the head waters of the Hudson river.
They give glowing accounts of the military career and achievements of General Wool, and declare that they cannot conjecture why he is not placed in active duty.
They cannot conjecture!
Why not ask Gen. Scott for as explanation?
Possibly he can give them some information.

div3.head: Out the Secrege.
div3.p:
--We received a letter, some days ago, from the vicinity of Norfolk, giving an account of the capture of an expedition to secure a cargo of coffee in a wrecked vessel on the North Carolina coast, which the Lincolnites were said to be watching.
We deemed it prevalent to suppress the information; but now learn that the cargo, consisting of some 4,400 bags, was secured without difficulty.
A portion of it will be brought to Richmond.

div3.head: Invasion by way of the Valley.
div3.p:
The obvious design of the enemy is to get into Virginia by large columns of troops thrown upon our left flank, under Gens. Johnston at Winchester, and Garnett at Laurel Hill.
It is very evident that most of his attention has been directed to his affairs in that quarter for several weeks.
The announcement by the Tribune of an immediate attack upon Gen. Beauregard's command before Alexandria, and the parade of crossing troops over the bridge from Washington to this side of the Potomac, may be regarded as feints, to distract attention from the real design of entering our State in force by way of the Valley.
The mutiny of Pennsylvania regiments at Martinsburg may delay the march of Patterson's column; but, in all probability, there will be fighting of an important character at Laurel Hill, if not at Winchester, in a very short time, possibly before these lines are published.

Many advantages would attend the success of this plan of campaign.
Virginia would, be entered in the healthful and comparatively cool region of the Valley, a country teeming in provisions of all sorts, and admirable for the summer operations of an army.
The citizens of the Valley of Virginia are amongst the most loyal of our people to the cause of the South, which they have testified by the number and excellent character of the troops they have put into the field.
To invade this region and to suppress the spirit of loyalty there, would weaken the energies of Virginia materially in this struggle, and proportionately cripple the Southern strength.
This portion of the State is also immediately contiguous to the realm of the Yankee Pierpont and to annex it to his dominions would add greatly to the dignity and consequence of that piratical Government in the Northwest, of which Pierpont and Upton, Carlile and Willey are the worthy representatives.
It would give those pretenders one-third of the area of Virginia, and more than a third of the white population; and it might lay the foundation for an ultimate division of Virginia, in the final arrangements for settling the terms of a division of the old Union.

The military advantages of this invasion of Virginia by way of the Valley would be as great as its political.
Beauregard's column would be passed and that General would be in the condition so much abhorred by Scott, of having an enemy in the rear as well as in the front.
Staunton would probably be made the first object to be secured, from which central point operations could be planned at leisure against other portions of the State, including Richmond.
The possession of Staunton and the Valley by the enemy, would go very far towards giving them possession of all West Virginia, except the Southwest.

If the enemy does not succeed in this plan of invading the State, we are inclined to think his chance of getting in at all is very bad. His first design was to take Norfolk and to move against Richmond by the Yorktown peninsula and the James River.
But Norfolk is now impregnable, and his experiences in the peninsula have cured him of all expectations of success in that quarter. --At Aquia Creek his fortune has been no better, and at Alexandria the game has been blocked against him. To achieve success at these points could only be through forces greatly disproportioned to those he would have to encounter.

His only hope is by way of Martinsburg and Phillippi.
He has accordingly placed as many as forty-five thousand troops under the command of Patterson, and it is not known how many, under that of McClellan, for a demonstration upon the Valley of Virginia.
It now remains to be seen what luck he will have in that quarter.
We do not fear the result.
He will find a lion in his path there, as well as at Manassas, at Aquia and at Bethel.
There will be more fighting, and fighting on a larger scale, than we have yet had, but we are confident the result will be the same.--Even if he should achieve the impossible feat of whipping us in pitched battles, his task will only then have just begun.
Our forces would be seconded by the militia of the Valley; and every mountain pass, every tree, and every hill side would be charged with the messengers of death.

This plan of invasion is ably conceived, and would seem to have promised an easier success than any other; but we venture to predict that the attempt to carry it into execution will bring more disaster upon the enemy than he has yet had to encounter.
Nous verrons.

div3.head: Exeter Hall.
div3.p:
We have seen it stated among other items of foreign intelligence, that at a meeting of Exeter Hall Abolitionists in London, the prevailing expression of sentiment was in favor of a dissolution of the American Union, on the ground that such an event would hasten the abolition of slavery.
If this be so, the only party in England which could be expected to oppose the recognition of the Southern Confederacy may be considered "out of the ring."

It has been before observed that the Abolitionists proper of our own country are not among the most prominent champions of the present war. The speech of Wendell Phillips, some time ago, in opposition to it may afford some clue to their position and policy.
Strange to say, Edward Everett is a stronger advocate of the war, and a more faithful representative of the spirit and purposes of the Lincoln Administration than Wendell Phillips. The secret of it all is, that the war is a commercial and not an abolition war. The declaration of the New York Times, that the slaveholders are to be punished, but still permitted, under sundry burthens, losses and inconveniences, to retain the institution, discloses the real policy of the war party.
This the Abolitionists have not been slow to discover, and hence, being honest in their madness, they are lukewarm in such a cause.

It is strange, but as true as true as strange, that the Conservatives and not the Abolitionists are the enemy with whom we have now to deal.
They will be baffled in their mercenary purposes both by the capacity of the South to maintain a successful resistance, and the loss of the only friendship abroad which could have given them countenance.
But, even if the South should fall, she would have vengeance in her own hands, for she would desolate every acre of her own soil, and, like Samson, pull down the temple of national strength with her, and involve her enemies and herself in a a common ruin.

div3.head: Rebels and pirates.
div3.p:
The military and civil authorities of the Lincoln Government may rest assured that the moment they carry into execution their barbarous threat of treating their prisoners as rebels and pirates, two of their own men will swing for every one of ours.
We have already a large number of prisoners, and no opportunity will be neglected to seize and hold as many hostages as possible for the good conduct of the enemy.

div3.head: All right.
div3.p: --In Raleigh, N. C., they are moulding minute balls and making cartridges by the hundred thousand. Mr. Palmer, at the Deaf and Dumb Asylum, has a large number of patriotic boys and girls at work in the business.
Commodore Tutnal invites proposals for the construction, by contract, of five small vessels for the C. S. service.

div3.head: Col. Fremont.
div3.p:
We have heard a rumor that the splendid military career of Gen. Butler in Virginia is about drawing to a close, and that his place is to be supplied by Gen. Fremont. If so, we may expect renewed energy, and perhaps more intelligence upon the enemy's line of operations in the peninsula.
Gen. Fremont, however, though a superior person to Gen. Butler, has never achieved any remarkable reputation as a soldier.
A man of science, and a successful explorer, but never has been suspected of being a General.
We predict that he will not meet with more success in his military campaign to reach Richmond than in his Presidential campaign to reach Washington.
The peninsula must by this time be thoroughly defended at every point, and the heroes of Bethel Church and their gallant comrades are ready to give the foe another taste of their quality.

Other accounts, however, assign to Colonel Fremont a different field of action.
We shall be sorry to lose Butler from our own neighborhood, on many accounts.
In a military point of view, he is invaluable; as a suggester of mirth-inspiring images, he is more comic than Placide in "Bombastes Purioso," or Hackett in "Sir John Falstaff." So long as Butler remains at Old Point, the dismal fact of its occupancy by Federal troops will be somewhat relieved by the ludicrousness of such a commander.

div3.head: Absurdities of the Northern press.
div3.p: The proposition of the New York Herald that the North and South should relinquish their quarrel and unite their forces for the purpose of waging war upon England and France, is worthy the sagacity and statesmanship which characterize that paper.

A discussion of this original scheme of the Herald would be almost as absurd as the proposition itself, but it strikingly illustrates the recklessness and fatuity of the guides of public opinion and the sources of popular intelligence in the North, when the leading journal of the great Northern emporium deals gravely in such preposterous, lunatic suggestions.
Equally crazy is the New York Tribune, which seriously sets forth as among the consequences of Southern success, that the South will come domineering back into the old Union, and flourish its "slaveholder's whip about Washington" in its ancient truculent and overbearing style!
Nothing could better exhibit the hopeless ignorance which prevails in the North of Southern character and purposes, than such speculations as these, of the two principal journals in the North.

div3.head: The bogus Virginia Government.
div3.p: --We have forborne the impalement in type of the coterie of precious worthies who constitute the bogus Virginia Government, until we could give a diagnosis, as it were, of each.--And, really, they are a lovely set.

And as Dogberry would say, "in the first place, firstly," we commence with the delectable Pierpont, ye Governor: His chivalry and pluck is unquestionable, as his person is large.
No better selection could have been made of a man to rule over the valiant Abolitionists of Northwestern Virginia, as Pierpont only permitted himself, during the trial of a cause in Taylor county, to be knocked down with an inkstand in the Court-House by a lawyer, born in Eastern Virginia, who was small in person, without either the spirit or courage to resent the affront.
So we propose, that as his schemes are as black as his associates, and the missile with which he was floored, that he shall be hereafter called the "Inkstand Governor."

Next comes the virtuous Paisley, ye "Lieutenant Governor," who deserves preservation "like a fly in amber," or perhaps as a more congenial and appropriate encasement for him, we should say, ambler. This bijou of a man is at present a resident of Jackson county.
His life has been migratory.
After various tradings, he became a fifteen shilling lawyer, and essayed practice in the Pan Handle town of Wellsburg.
From here he took up his tramp to the county of his present residence, and what, with swindling and shaving, has managed to amass some money.
He is a fit Lieutenant under Captain "Inkstand."

Nathan Wilson is the Secretary of the Commonwealth.
(We suppose this means the $27,000 that Pierpont stole from the Weston Bank.) This jewel No. 3 was born in the Camden and Amboy State of New Jersey, and was raised in the Metropolitan hot-bed of Abolitionism, Boston.
Should there ever be anything that even approximated Commonwealth, it will be very uncommon with him if he does not handle a good share of it.
S. P. Hildreth, ye "Treasurer," is a noted Black Republican, and voted for the Ll. D. Lincoln. His office will, we fear, prove a sinecure, unless they can rob a few more Banks.

Wilson, who, as we do not know his first name, we can appropriately designate as blank Wilson, has rejoiced with exceeding joy as a seller of dry goods in Wheeling.
From calico he has been called to preside over parchment, as Clerk to the House of Delegates.
This is gem No. 4.

But chiefest among the number, and "altogether lovely," is Jim Hawley the incorrupt and incorruptible Sergeant-at-Arms.--This precious scoundrel is a whilom police officer, and if he were capable of discharging honestly his former calling, would no doubt make any number of arrests among the rogues with whom he is now officially associated.

We came near omitting any mention of that luminous, or rather voluminous body, yclept the "Virginia Legislature." It is composed of two Houses; the first, called the Senate, has actually three members; the latter designated as the House of Delegates, comprises twenty-seven members.
This number is most fortunate for them, for it is said that on the commencement of their sitting they were compelled to go on tick for their liquor and grub; but they have now passed a resolution to the effect that whereas the Bank at Weston was robbed of twenty-seven thousand dollars, which sum had been brought to Wheeling, and whereas twenty-seven was the exact number of their honorable body, therefore that each member take a thousand dollars and say no more about it. This resolution is said to have passed new con.

div3.head: Citizens' oath.
div3.p:
--The citizens of Pensacola held a public meeting recently and appointed a committee of safety, to look after all the inhabitants.
The Observer publishes the names of 524 citizens who have taken the following oath:

q.p:
"I do most sincerely and solemnly swear before Almighty God, without mental reservation of any kind, that I will support and defend the Constitution of the Confederate States of America, and that I will in all things demean myself as a true and faithful citizen of the said Confederate States; and I do promise that I will endeavor to discover, and will report, any and every unfaithful person of whom I may obtain reliable intelligence.
So help me God."

div3.head: The militia.
div3.p:
--When the Rockingham militia left Harrisonburg, the ladies presented them with two beautiful flags, and patriotic speeches were made on the occasion.
The Register says:

q.p:
We think we are authorized to say for our strong-armed raw militia of Rockingham, that though, owing to circumstances, they have been the last to get to the field, yet the enemy will find them as bold and as determined, if not as well drilled, as the best volunteer soldiers who have gone to the wars.
We confidently expect a good account of the Rockingham militia.

div3.head: The Derux Regiment.
div3.p: --We learn that this regiment, which is to be commanded by Col. S. F. Marks, and of which that gallant gentlemen, Lieut. Sam McKneely, of Pointe Coupee, is to be an officer, is now nearly completed, and will probably leave next week for the seat of war. This regiment has been regularly organized by the Secretary of War, and with its gallant, experienced, and veteran Colonel, will prove one of the most effective in the service.-- N. O. Detta, 10th.
Col. Jacob S. Foute, a well known citizen of Jackson, Miss., died recently, He was a native of Baltimore.

div3.head: The Government loan.
div3.p:
The loan for the defence of the Confederate States, called for by the act of Congress, is being most liberally responded to throughout the entire South.
The attention of the people in almost every county, (says the Montgomery Advertiser), has been called to the subject, and everywhere the greatest enthusiasm is manifested.
The planters are freely subscribing their cotton and corn, and those who have no crop to pledge are subscribing in money.
So universal a determination on the part of the people to lend aid to the Government of their choice was never before seen.
There is still room, however, and those who have not already subscribed, yet have a chance to do so. No one should hesitate in this matter.
The bonds of the Government are better than any other security that can be furnished.
They will bring to the holders eight per cent. per annum, besides being as good as gold.
Interest and patriotism alike call upon the people of the South to swell this loan to as large an amount as possible.
No matter if the subscriptions should reach a sum double the wants of the Government.
The moral effect of such an exhibition of confidence in the stability of the Government would be powerful abroad.

The staple productions of the South now control the markets of the world.
Nearly a thousand millions of foreign capital depend upon the production of cotton, tobacco, etc. In England alone, more than five millions of people are dependent upon the cotton fields of the South for the bread they eat. Without their yearly supply, they would be forced to starve.
The extent of this power, which the Southern people hold in their hands, cannot well be overestimated.
If properly used, it will yet open to the Confederate States the ports of all nations, and bring to our shores the commerce of every land.
By loaning a portion of the crops of the South to the Government, we clothe it with the power of the country, and enable it to exert an influence among those nations with whom it may be desirable to negotiate.

Whatever remains to be done in this matter should be done quickly.
The commissioners appointed to solicit subscriptions will soon be ready to make their report.
It is desirable that every man who has the means should take this opportunity of testifying his willingness to support the cause of the people of the South.
No sacrifice of interest is required.
The man who takes a Confederate bona in exchange for his crop gets the full value of that crop.

The Northern despot has called for four hundred thousand men and four hundred millions of dollars to be used in subduing the people of the South.
His minions are now on Southern soil, plundering and murdering the inhabitants.
The homes of Southern men are consigned to the flames, and their churches desecrated by the wretches who have been sent to bind and rivet upon us the chains of tyranny, and shall it be said that Southern people hesitated a moment to furnish their Government with ample means to drive the invaders from our soil, and secure the blessings of liberty and peace?
The answer has already been given, and it will be reiterated time and again so long as there shall be any need for aid.

div3.head:
The Atrocious Message of President Lincoln.
[from the New York Daily News.]
div3.p:
The unscrupulous Chief Magistrate who presides over the destinies of the United States, has fairly convicted himself, out of his own mouth, and by his own avowals, of the worse crimes of which he accuses his Southern enemies.
By what right does he call Jefferson Davis and the leaders of the Secession movement 'traitors?' It by no other than that they have taken up arms, unlawfully, as he alleges, against the peace of the United States, then he, Abraham Lincoln, is equally guilty of treason, for he acknowledges that he has violated his oath of office, levied armies, invaded States, proclaimed martial law, and perpetrated various other illegal acts tending to bloodshed, on the simple trust that Congress would ratify his unconstitutional conduct — He says:--"The attention of the country has been called to the proposition that one who is sworn to take care that the laws be faithfully executed should not himself violate them," and he replies:--"Would not the official oath be broken if the Government should be overthrown, when it was believed that disregarding a single law would tend to preserve it?" Was ever reasoning more monstrous, more wicked?
Judged from the most favorable point of view, it means that "two wrongs make a right," and that illegal action on the part of the Southern Confederacy affords ample justification for counter iniquities on the part of the Administration.

They are still passive, while they behold breach after breach made in the fortress of the Constitution.
Let them beware, lest before long the battlements are dismantled, when the citadel will be open to the invader, the walls totter, and the fortress be no longer tenable.
No man who loves his country can witness the present state of things without alarm.
The delusive cry of "Government being in danger" but conceals the certain result — the subversion of all the liberties of the people.
The cry for "loans and regiments" is that usurpation and tyranny may surround themselves with the only defence they can rely upon — the bayonets of the military — and provide themselves with the only resources they ever resort to — unjust taxes upon an oppressed people.

div3.head: From New York.
div3.p: --The New York correspondent of the Philadelphia Ledger says:

q.p:
There is a great deal of gossip in certain circles here in regard to the burning of the steamer Cataline, on Thursday last, near Fortress Monroe, but it is of such a character that it will scarcely do to repeat.
It will do no harm, however, to say the Cataline, like many other craft recently sold to the Government, was a very old concern, furnished up and chartered to the Government as a mere business speculation, by a clique of well-known politicians, one of whom is an ex-member of Congress, a resident of Utica, another the proprietor of a Broadway Hotel, and the third a well known lawyer.
It is a fact that the steamer was chartered at the enormous sum of $10,000 a mouth, with the proviso that $50,000 should be paid the owners should the boat be destroyed while in Government service: It is also a fact that the steamer is insured in Wall street for $25,000. So that her destruction must yield a handsome return to the parties interested.
The truth is, this affair will turn out, if investigated, a huge job, the particulars of which will "astonish the natives," even of New York, familiar as they are with transactions of the kind.
A solemn High Mass was celebrated at Dr. Cummings' Church, yesterday, for the repose of the soul of the late Signor Amodio, of whose death all doubt would now seem to be dissipated.

Two of the city Theatres have still the courage to keep their doors open — Laura Keen's and the Winter Garden — but neither is more than barely paying expenses.
Of music we have nothing at all, nor are we likely to have any till next fall.

The war is curtailing the dimensions of the hebdominal, as well as the daily press.
The Dispatch to-day is out in a half sheet, and the Leader ditto.
The same cause is operating disastrously upon one or two of the "sensation" weeklies, and their speedy suspension is by no means improbable.

The prospective tax upon tea, coffee, sugar and molasses for war purposes — as recommended by the Secretary of the Treasury--has had the effect to stiffen the prices of some of these articles, in this market.
Most descriptions of sugars are from ¼ to ¾ cents per pound dearer.
The importers of teas, as a general thing, are withdrawing their stocks from the market.
Coffee being in abundant supply, prices are unaffected, though the belief is that an advance is inevitable if Congress seconds the Secretary's recommendations.

div3.head: The war spirit in the West.
div3.p:
--The Lincoln dupes at the North have been taught by their masters to believe that the people of Western Virginia require their protection — something, by the bye, which is very like what the wolf gives to the lamb.
The Kanawha Valley Star gives an idea of the real feelings of the people of that section, in the following:

q.p:
There are many men in this neighborhood capable of bearing arms who have not volunteered, who are now at home, but we know they are not idle; we are satisfied that securing our plentiful harvest of grain is serving the State as effectually as shooting an enemy.
The same blade before which now fails the life and strength-sustaining grain can easily deal out death to that corrupt growth of flesh and blood that now seeks our degradation.
Our farmers in this section of the State do their own work; they have few slaves; hence they cannot leave home at this time without suffering a material loss, which of course is a loss also to the State.
We are satisfied that the great heart of the people beats in sympathy with Virginia in her integrity.
Our people are scattered, removed from the excitement and sensation incident to a crowd at this time; they feel secure in their familiar and quiet homes; they make no public demonstrations, but they are ready.
They have rifles and powder and lead, and only wait the presence of the enemy, to teach him something of the guerilla.
Virginia will resist her enemies as long as she has bread and meat, powder and lead, the means of sustaining and destroying life.

div3.head: The double-barrel shot gun.
div3.p: --Gen. Pillow publishes the following card in the Memphis papers:

q.p:
Mr. John Creighton, of Memphis, has shown me a double-barrel shot gun, to which he has affixed a bayonet, making it a most formidable weapon.
I am satisfied that the double-barrel shot gun, with the Minnie ball and sword bayonet attached, is as deadly a weapon and would be as efficient on the battle field as the troops could be armed with.--The country is full of these arms, and with them fifty thousand more troops could be thrown into the field for the public defence, and I advise all men having a double-barrel shot gun to have the bayonet attached.
The bayonet is easily fixed and unfixed in a moment of time.

div3.head: The militia called out.
div3.p:
--It will be seen by a notice published elsewhere, that the constituted authorities are initiating measures for calling out the militia to aid in driving the invaders from our soil.
We will not permit ourselves to doubt for an instant but that the call will be heartily responded to. It is both the part of patriotism and duty to rush to the aid of the imperilled liberties of our common country.

As there are at least two thousand young men in this city subject to militia duty, and who have no special "binding tie" to keep them from doing their duty in this contest, we insert the following communication, which will serve as a "reminder" to some "weary spirits" who would no doubt be willing to forego the pleasure of serving their country.
The communication, written to the Dispatch, says:

q.p:
"We have deemed it proper to call your attention to the fact that since the militia have been called out there are many able-bodied young men who profess to have attached themselves to volunteer companies, have not enrolled their names, and they spend their time in visiting those companies for a few days and then return to their homes for as many weeks, intending thereby to avoid enrollment in the militia and all duties imposed upon the regular volunteers, such as drilling, standing guard, &c. The captains of the volunteer companies, not considering them regular members, take little heed of them, while their men extend the hospitalities of the camp in the hope of inducing them to become regular members by enrolling their names.
This sort of dissimulation and low cunning to avoid military duty altogether should be exposed, and the officers in command put on the alert so that such trickery may be stopped, and such individuals brought down to peremptory service in one corps or the other.

"There is another subject to which I would draw your attention, viz: that some prompt and efficient step should be taken with these Union men, stuck here and there in our midst, and ready to give aid and comfort to the enemy.
They furnish, when practicable, substitutes in the army, and remain at home devising plans by which to welcome and ingratiate themselves into the good graces of the enemy when he comes, and to point out Secessionists for plunder and outrage, that an immunity may be thrown around their persons and property.
Such men should be made to take the oath of allegiance to the Confederate Government, and otherwise dealt with according to the enormity of their acts and crimes.
Our Convention, when in session, should have taken this matter under serious consideration for the safety of loyal citizens and their property, and for the efficiency of the military forces now in the field.
These forces, where such characters exist, can make no surprise march, and when the enemy approaches they become conductors, leading him through the difficult and dangerous passes, secret paths and byways, so as to entrap or surprise our citizens and soldiers, as was the case in Alexandria, and more recently in the town of Romney, Hampshire county.
This is an important, indispensably important, evil to be corrected as promptly as possible.
More anon."

div3.head: Relief Society.
div3.p:
--The ladies of Powhatan county have organized themselves into a society, to be called the Powhatan Relief Society, as auxiliary to the one already formed in Richmond, the object of which is to minister, as far as they can to the wants of our sick and wounded soldiers.
The Powhatan ladies say:

q.p:
We propose to do this, not only by voluntary contributions of money, but by sending to the parent society, for distribution in various camps, such articles of food suitable for the sick as we can spare from our own families.
Indeed, we feel willing to deny ourselves to supply them.
We are pained to hear of the sufferings and want of comforts in some of our camps; and, while we appreciate most highly the noble patriotism which has called so many from home comforts to the defence of our soil and rights, we are determined to do all in our power to lessen their sufferings.

We sympathize with all, but most especially do we feel our hearts moved within us, when we think of the strangers among us who are sick — those noble sons of the South, who, disregarding everything but liberty and honor, have speedily assembled on our soil, to present their bodies, along with our own gallant sons, as an "adamantine wall," to prevent the farther invasion of our homes or firesides by the wicked Hamans of the North.
Shall we let such suffer for the want of the tender care of those mothers, wives and sisters left far behind?

No! Never. While we would not neglect our own loved ones, we wish the Southern soldiers to share equally with them in the comforts we send, thus complying with the divine injunction of doing unto others as we would that they should do to us. We have sons and brothers, dear to our hearts, in the tented field; and in the changing scenes of war we know not how soon they may be sent far away from us; then we will want the mothers and sisters in that part of our Confederacy to extend to them the care and sympathy which none but such can give.
Let us do the same.

div3.head: New Volunteer Company.
div3.p:
--G. A. Wallace, of the firm of William Wallace Son's, a gentleman of intelligence, worth and enterprise, has engaged his energies for some weeks past in raising a volunteer company for the war, in this city, in which undertaking, we are pleased to say, he has been eminently successful.
The writer, an old schoolmate of "Gus," knows that his men will be in charge of a kind and considerate commander, who, while paying due regard to strict military discipline, will take good care to see that they are well provided for. The commander of the new company, who will, as we happen to know, be aided by the most competent aids, is furnishing everything to his men free of cost — armory, lodging, board and uniforms.
He has already 50 good men, and would like to have fifty more.
To all endowed with the proper spirit of patriotism, whose narrow means have hitherto prevented them from joining a volunteer company, this arrangement of Captain Wallace's offers rare inducements.

The company will be armed with the splendid Mississippi rifle, with sword bayonet — Those desiring to connect themselves with a well equipped company, under a first-rate leader, should call at once at the recruiting office, on 13th street, between Main and Cary.

div3.head: The Hospital on 26th street.
div3.p:
--Since the establishment of this hospital it has done great good to the sick soldiers who have been brought thither from the different encampments located in its immediate vicinity.
The ladies and gentlemen resident in its direct neighborhood have been untiring in their exertions to see that the invalids wanted for nothing that kindness could suggest or money buy. This is all very right as far as it goes, but the burthen of care and attention should not be imposed on a few patriotic individuals who happen to live in close proximity to the hospital.
As the soldiers who are brought there sick come to fight for all — the inhabitants both of Union and Church Hills individually and collectively — each and all should contribute their might to restore them to health.
This course is called for by patriotism and duty both.
It is hardly more than necessary to mention this matter, we feel assured, to have it properly and efficiently attended to. The ladies have done themselves all honor by the manner in which they have ministered to the wants of our disabled defenders.

div3.head: Live Yankees.
div3.p:
--Such a rush as there is to the windows of the hotels on Main street every few days when the Yankee prisoners are marshalled through the town, one would think live Yankees must have undergone some wonderful transformation of late.
Do the ladies and children, who are so eager to get a peep at them, expect to see them armed with wings? or rather, perhaps, with horns and hoofs!
Yankees have been common enough among us, heaven knows, and plenty are still left, who require to be somewhat carefully tended.
By the way, would it not be as well to divide our prisoners among the hospitable inhabitants of our larger towns, now that they are getting so abundant among us. Lynchburg and Petersburg might have the honor of entertaining a few.

If the Northern President could take a peep at Richmond some fine day he would think he had not yet made much progress towards "subjugating the South." The streets and park are thronged with cheerful faces, and groups of soldiers everywhere lounging and laughing.
Let him peep in at the hotels of an evening and listen to the music and mirth within and serenades without.
Let him gaze upon the well stocked tables, and visit the markets, and he will be inclined to give up the task as hopeless.
Above all, let him hear a few sentiments expressed by some of our servants, and he will find his own toiling, starving poor, more worthy objects of his chivalry.

div3.head: Soldier drowned.
div3.p:
--A soldier attached to one of the companies encamped at Howard's Grove was found floating in the dock on Saturday.
The body, which had on it a sum of money, was removed by the Captain of the corps to which deceased was attached.
We could not learn the name of the unfortunate man.

div3.head: Gregg's Regiment.
div3.p:
--Three companies of Col. Maxcy Gregg's First Regiment South Carolina volunteers are encamped near this city, and are now ready for service.
They have been performing the latter for over six months, but are still willing to go on till the war is ended and Southern independence secured.
The men of the above regiment, whose time being out, have availed themselves of the opportunity to go home and visit their relatives, will soon be back.
Their gallant commander, Maxcy Gregg, has been appointed a Colonel in the Confederate States Army.
Like his men, he is as true as steel and firm as the granite of the everlasting hills.

div3.head: Recruiting.
div3.p:
--A large number of the free negro population of Richmond appeared at the City Hall on Saturday to enrol their names as operatives on the fortifications now being erected around the city.
They were informed that at the conclusion of each day's work they could come to the city if they saw fit. If they answered promptly to the roll-call, they would get fed and paid; if they did not, they would get something else.
What that was the Mayor, who was spokesman of the magistrates, did not say. The force who will go down this morning will no doubt be a large one.

div3.head: Personal.
div3.p:
--The following gentlemen, with others, were registered at the Exchange Hotel yesterday, viz: J. S. Barbour, Jr., Culpeper; Lieut. A. Bates, Hampton's Legion; S. B. Robertson, Second Regiment Louisiana Volunteers; J. F. Collins, Miss.; R. B. Stephens, Gloucester Point; L. Mims, Mississippi; Joseph Littlejohn, New Orleans; Colonel W. F. Wilson, Winchester.
At the Spotswood House: Jas. Chestnut, Jr., Manassas Junction; J. Farrer, Mobile; W. P. Webb, Eutaw, Alabama; S. R. Davidson, Lynchburg; J. A. Dalby, Farmville; R. Bayne, Alexandria, Va.

div3.head: Texas troops.
div3.p:
--The gallant "Lone Star" State is still sending her brave sons to the protection of the soil of Virginia and the South.
There will arrive in this city, perhaps to-day, two fine companies from the vicinity of Palestine, Anderson county, Texas. One of them will be commanded by Col. A. T. Rainey, and the other by Capt. Wm. A. Woodward--both as gallant and chivalrous men as can be found in the ranks of any army.
We welcome them to our soil.

div3.head: Col. Wade Hampton.
div3.p:
--This gentleman, who commands the splendid South Carolina Legion, encamped near this city, is the possessor of a princely fortune, and has been for many years prominent in the political affairs of his State.
His library at Greenville, S. C., contains ten or twelve thousand volumes, including about fifteen hundred on American history.
The library fills two large rooms, and cost, probably, twenty thousand dollars.

div3.head: Drunken men.
div3.p:
--Thirteen white men were incarcerated in the lock-up, Old Market, Saturday night for drunkenness.
Most of them were Sons of Mars, who had taken time by the forelock and got in their Sunday supply of whiskey Saturday night. The bar-rooms were all closed yesterday.

The Pluvial Visitations have been numerous lately.
The crops have manifestly been benefitted.
The streets were very thoroughly cleansed by the showers which fell on Saturday evening. The rain certainly comes in good time now.

div3.head:
By the Governor of Virginia.
a proclamation.
div3.p:
We have been taught by our fathers that the Militia, composed of the body of the people, trained to arms, is the proper, natural and safe defence of a free State.
In time of need, therefore, it is proper to resort to this natural resource.
We are called upon to defend all that is dear to freemen.
We are called upon to drive from our land an insolent foe, who is threatening us with subjugation and overthrow.
Confident that every true Virginian possesses the nerve and the soul to give his hand and his heart to prevent this fell purpose — the Militia is called to arms.
This call will not be unheeded.

Having received through the Secretary of War a requisition from the President of the Confederate States, calling into immediate service the militia of all the counties north of James river and East of the Blue Ridge, as well as all the militia in the Valley of the State, north of James river, it is proper that this call should be promptly met. It is proper at all times to be prepared for any emergency, and to offer resistance with the energy and power necessary to ensure success.
If required, we shall rely upon the entire force of the residue of the State.
Every man that can bear arms, must in turn give his willing assistance.
Never in the history of nations has a people so eagerly and promptly met every call upon them.
No man will come his efforts now until we have been crowned with victory.

Now, therefore, in conformity with the requisition of the President of the Confederate States, L. John Letcher, Governor of the Commonwealth of Virginia, by the authority vested in the Executive by law, do hereby require the regiments of the counties designated in the list hereto annexed, to assemble forthwith at the several places specified, in the most prompt and efficient manner.

Under this call, every field officer, in the counties designated, will immediately call out each company remaining in his regiment not heretofore ordered; and where, from any cause, companies have been diminished below their required strength, two or more must be united, and the oldest company officer, among those thrown together, will assume the command of the company thus formed.

Company officers of every grade will forthwith summon their men, and the commandants will take care immediately to enrol all persons, heretofore omitted, who are subject to militia duty within their respective company districts, and report their companies and the strength of each to the commandant of their regiment.

Commandants of regiments, as soon as companies are reported, will organize them into battalions, and dispatch each battalion, as formed, to the place of rendezvous indicated.
If but one battalion can be formed, the Commandant of the regiment will take command until a regiment be organized.
When assembled at the rendezvous herein designated, the senior officer present will unite the battalions into regiments, keeping those belonging to the same regiment together, and the senior field officer of the regiment or regiments, where two or more are united, present and capable of duty, will asssume the command of it.

Commandants of regiments will forthwith appoint their Regimental Quartermasters and Commissaries under the law of the State, and will order them to proceed forthwith to the place appointed for the rendezvous of their regiments to provide for the militia as they assemble.

Each member of a company will provide himself with any arms to be obisined, without regard to the description, whether rifle, musket, carbine or shot gun, and carry with him all the ammunition suitable to his arm that he can procure.
When regiments are formed each commandant will immediately report to the Governor the number of arms necessary to complete the arming of his regiment.
Officers and privates of the militia in the active volunteer service of the State will continue in that service, and are exempt from this call.
Given under my hand as Governor, and under the seal of the Commonwealth of Virginia, this 13th day of July, 1861, and in the year of the Commonwealth.
John Leicher.
div3.closer:
By the Governor:
George W. Munford.
Secretary of the Commonwealth.

div3.head: The reason why.
div3.p:
--I have been often asked why I do not advertise my patent Camp Bed, and my Newly Constructed Table, that can be neatly folded and laid in the chest?
The reason is, that as I well them as fast as they can be made, there is no necessity for it. The object of this notice is to inform those interested, that if they will call at the Factory, on 8th street, between Grace and Franklin streets, they will be shown something different, and far superior to anything I have seen, in my judgment, and I thus give the invitation, that others may judge for themselves.
jy 15--3t* Wm. Forbes.

J. D. K. Sleight, R. S.

div3.head: To Railroad and other Contractors.
div3.p:
--Sealed proposals for erecting fortifications around the city will be received by the Committee on Defence until Friday next, 10th inst., at 12 M. The wood work will be put up by hands engaged by the Committee, and the contractor will only be required to excavate the earth and deposit it as directed by the engineer in charge of the works.
The proposals must be made out in this form:

p.q:
"The undersigned will undertake the work of erecting one or more redoubts near the city of Richmond at the rate of ... cents per square yard.
The number of yards to be paid for to be ascertained by measuring the ditch after the work is completed, and I will engage to have (insert the number) hands at work upon the same.
[signed.]"

div3.p: Any information in regard to the character of the work can be obtained by examining the works on Marion Hill, or by enquiring of Mr. Richard Reine at Redoubt No. 4.
Proposals will be addressed to
Thomas H. Wyner.
--5t Chairman Committee on Defence.
