div3.head:
Fight near Laurel Hill.
additional particulars.
[special correspondence of the Dispatch.]
div3.p: We continue the intelligence from our special correspondent, commenced on the first page.

div4.p: I wrote you a short account of the engagement the command of Gen. Garnett and the enemy had a few days since, and have since learned additional particulars.

The force of the enemy is estimated at between 7,000 and 8,000, and advanced from Phillippi on Saturday and took up a position on a hill about a mile and a half from our post, which, however, is obstructed from the view of our troops by a still higher hill directly between them and ourselves.
On learning of their advance, our General checked their advance by taking possession of a hill to the left of them, and on Sunday morning about daybreak the two commenced operations, our force consisting of only one company of Georgians and theirs' of a larger number, constituting the advance guard.
This company held their own until about 2 o'clock, when they were relieved by the 23d Regiment, (Col Taliaferro.) The Georgians succeeded in killing five or six of the enemy, but received from them not even a scratch, although the Yankees kept up a severe fire upon them.

On the arrival of Col. Taliaferro's command, the Richmond Sharp-Shooters, being armed with superior arms, were placed in advance, and took up a position closer than that occupied by the Georgia company.
The company had no sooner taken their proper place, when they opened briskly on the foe, which was returned as briskly; but few of the return shots did any execution, save to nerve us to extra exertion.
We continued our fire until relieved by Col. Fulkerson's Washington County Regiment, at 7 o'clock. The Sharp-Shooters succeeded in killing between 25 and 30 of the enemy.
Our loss was private Charles H. Goff, of Richmond city, killed instantly, and Captain Harrison and Sergeant Thad. Bosher, of the Goochland Grays, slightly wounded.

In alluding to this company, I do not wish, nor is it my desire to detract from the remainder of the regiment, for a braver set of men can scarcely be found; but in the engagement of Sunday, they could not, with the arms they have, have reached the enemy, being too far off, nor could they have gotten a closer position.
In fact, the whole regiment done its duty faithfully and well, and I believe will ever continue to do so. It is composed of the following companies and officers: The Amelia Grays, Capt. Perkinson; Brooklyn (Halifax) Grays, Capt. Hames; Louisa Grays, Capt. Sergeant; Frederick Hall Grays, Capt. Coleman; Goochland Grays, Captain Harrison; Central (Prince Edward) Guard, Capt. Hughes; Keysville (Charlotte) Guard, Capt. Walton; Amelia Rifles, Capt. Scott; Louisa Rifles, Capt. Walton, and the Richmond Sharp-Shooters, Captain R A. Tompkins, all under the command of Col. Wm. B. Taliaferro, with the following assistants: James R. Crenshaw, of Richmond, Lieutenant Colonel; Jos. Pendleton, Maj.; W. B. Pendleton, of Louisa, Adjutant; Dr. Wm. A. Carrington, of Charlotte, Surgeon; Dr. Jacob M. Deems, of the same county, Assistant Surgeon; Dr. Winston, of Louisa, Quartermaster — all good and true men, who have the confidence and respect of all the command.
The Surgeons are attentive and well skilled, and do all in their power to relieve those who suffer from sickness, and have been fortunate, so far in their restoration of a number of patients.--The Hospital Steward, Dr. Angle, also deserves credit for the manner in which he performs his laborious duty.
The firing was continued all night by the regiment of Col. Fulkerson, with but little execution, however, as the night was very dark Certainly none of our troops were injured.

This regiment in turn was relieved by the gallant Georgians, under Col. Ramsey, at daybreak Monday morning, who, until a late hour in the day, kept up a continual fire upon them, and succeeded in killing six of the Yankees and taking a Lieutenant prisoner.
The number of them wounded of course cannot be ascertained.
The Georgians left the ground in the afternoon, with not a man killed or even a scratch.

During the latter part of the day the enemy fired a number of bomb shells, grape-shots and balls in the direction of our troops, playing havoc with the trees and shrubbery, not in the least damaging any of our men, but with a loss to them of a large amount of powder.
In consequence of the rapid discharge of artillery, our General sent out two regiments (the 23d and 20th) to sustain the Georgians, but they did not succeed in getting a chance at the enemy, and during the night retired from the field, with the hope of inducing the foe to follow them, so as to get them in the range of our artillery.
It is supposed that our infantry and rifles had done such execution among them that the enemy got his "bile" up a little and let loose his big dogs of war, which, however, proved as harmless as his leaden pups.

The firing is still going on, (12 o'clock, Tuesday,) but I have not heard what damage has been done.
How long we are to continue this brush fighting it is hard to tell, but our troops are getting weary of it and are exceedingly anxious to get them in a face to face battle, and thus decide the contest.
I should have stated that the Yankees keep behind fences, brush, stumps, and have taken a log house, from which they have good shots at us. But for this, we would give you a larger number of their dead to record.

The Danville Artillery, as fine a body of men as can be seen anywhere, under the command of the gallant Captain Shoemaker, has not, as yet, had an opportunity of showing its hand; but when it gets a chance, the enemy may well look out, as the men are restless and eager for the fray.

A member of the Georgia Regiment was accidentally killed in camp, by the discharge of his piece, on Sunday morning. His name I could not learn.
His remains, and those of private Goff, were interred yesterday with military honors.

The commander of the Yankee troops, I have not yet learned.
Their troops are poorly clad, and appear to be of the lowest class of humanity, who, it seems, it would be doing the world a blessing to relieve of.

I shall give you farther accounts as they transpire.
The Dispatch is so much sought after that the Postmasters on the route take particular pains that they never reach their destination.
Soldiers suffer enough without being deprived of the pleasure of hearing from home — so give them a "talk" in your columns.
Ned.

p.hi: to the young men of the Northern Neck of Virginia.

div4.p:
It will be seen by the papers of recent date, that our Governor has issued a proclamation calling on the State for three thousand volunteers, in addition to the number now in service.
The Northern neck, as expressive of her loyalty to the noble cause of Southern independence, has already sent to the field many of her brave sons, whose gallant service in the hour of battle will win for them and for their section a name of honor to posterity.--With all this, however, it cannot be denied that her military strength is yet very considerable, and that she is now capable of almost, if not quite, doubling the number already furnished.
Lancaster county, it is true, has well nigh exhausted herself.
She is more exposed to the enemy perhaps than any other county, and yet, with the smallest population, has mustered into actual service five volunteer companies, four of which have given the parting hand to friends, and have gone to other fields of duty and danger, and the fifth one now in camp, guarding with vigilant eye her exposed borders.
It will readily be admitted that this is her full share, and that no more can or ought to be expected.
But how is it with other counties?
Come, fellow Southerners, let us reason together, desiring to do our whole duty.
The information in my possession as to the number of companies from each county may not be correct.--But, from all I can learn, Lancaster, in proportion to population, is in the advance.
This she does not boast of, nor mention by way of complaint; but simply in her zeal for the impregnable truth on which rests our common cause, that her sister counties may be reminded to cast about them, and see if they cannot do a little more.
Some of the counties referred to still muster pretty strong in the way of militia, and can probably spare many strong and brave men, whose very appearance would strike terror to the conscience-stricken hirelings of Northern despotism, while renewed impulses and courage would be given to those who have already left us. Cannot Northumberland furnish at least two more companies, Richmond one, Westmoreland two, and King George two or three, thus throwing together 7 or 8 companies, and greatly augmenting the military power of the States Extravagant as this estimate may at first appear, I verily believe that effort, determined effort, is all that is necessary to make it a reality.--Let suitable leaders in the various sections take the matter in hand and bring it to the consideration of the numerous and patriotic young men who, perhaps are only awaiting such an opportunity, and let no one indulge for a single moment the idea that he can be spared from the field to enjoy the blessings of a quiet home, while his fellow-countrymen and his neighbors are away off breasting the storm of war, and while the foul tread of the midnight assassin is already polluting our soil — while the miserable miscreants from the abodes of wretchedness are haunting our shores and thirsting for our blood, and while the blood of our country men is loudly calling to us from our own soil for vengeance on their murderers.
Under impulses of the liberty-loving spirit that animated our fathers, let us buckle on the armor of the soldier and promptly rally to the call of our noble old State, and
with a firm and abiding trust in the God of truth and justice, we may rest in the assurance that nought but a glorious triumph will await us.

argument.p: the Jackson Greys — presentation of a Flag — beautiful Address by a Lady.

div4.p: This book of Eastern Virginia has been greatly moved to-day by the departure of the Jackson Greys for the seat of war. They have been in camp for some time, drilling from four to six hours per day. The ladies have been engaged in making up their uniforms, and as a memento of their patriotism they presented the Greys with a beautiful flag, bearing the Virginia coat of arms upon one side, and upon the other the bright galaxy of eleven stars, looking forth from a blue field environed by oak and laurel.

The presentation was by Mrs. E. Wallace, in a chaste and eloquent speech, received by the young and gallant Captain Stewart in a stirring and patriotic reply.
The ceremonies were closed by the Rev. J. D. Berryman with an impressive appeal to High Heaven to vouchsafe unto our people the liberties for which they are now struggling.
Need I say how the heart of woman throbs in unison with this sentiment; how unremittingly she may be found at the Throne of Mercy, imploring Divine aid in this cause?
Then what of our men?
They are as firm, immovable and resistless as the everlasting mountains

Such a people can never be subjugated.
No, never.
The subjoined is the presentation speech of Mrs. W., which breathes forth so eloquently the spirit that pervades our people.
Sylvia.

Captain Stewart: While I cannot but feel proud of the compliment with which my sisters of St. Brides, the contributors to this beautiful banner, have honored me by selecting me to present it to you, I assure you and your gallant band that I am also proud to see such a goodly company interested in the scene.--One possessing youth and rosy loveliness might perform this chivalric duty with more grace and wit, but only a mother can feel the full force of what that duty implies.

While we are enjoying this sylvian scene, the green boughs waving above us, the song bird carolling notes of peace, and the very skies smiling upon the richly laden fields, our hearts are raised in gratitude to the Supreme Being who thus blesses us. Where there is no peace there can be no prosperity.
With peace and love, all our religious, literary and scientific, our agricultural and mechanical, our foreign and domestic institutions, flourish and grow like the pleasant scene around us; but our hearts turn with grief to the remembrance of the devastation of war. War!
in which only demons delight; and we burn with indignation at the remembrance of that despotic power whose double-tongued treachery, base falsehoods, unfulfilled promises and perversions of the Constitution of the United States and determined war-loving spirit has forced us into this terrible imbroglio.
May the God of battles reward him accordingly.

The patriotic spirit of our Southern soil is in vincible.
Every woman is a Joan of Arc, every child a Spartan; what, then, may be expected of our men?
Amid exploding shells and deafening cannon, they are dauntless!
and the heart of every soldier standing here beats with the sentiment of the immortal Jackson, whose name they bear.
Soldiers! I doubt not your valor; though you may feel the pang that our Washington felt upon his first entrance into battle, yet, like him, you will be nerved by the love of your country, your homes, your families.
Fortitude to bear the hardships and vicissitudes of camp life is as much to be valued as bravery on the battle field, and is powerfully conducive to that end.

lg.l: "Nobly dare the wildest storm,
Stem the hardest gale,
Brave of heart and strong of arm,
You will never fail,"

div4.p: and our ceaseless prayers shall ascend to Heaven for you.

Accept this flag.
May that galaxy of eleven stars ever wave triumphant, and never trail to the foe; and may Virginia's proud motto, "Sic Semper Tyrannis, " be fully vindicated, that the world may know that her long suffering and forbearance are not cowardice, and that the warm blood of her Washingtons, Henrys and Randolphs, has not grown cold and weak in the veins of their descendants; and may it stir the souls of your gallant men to conquer or to die.

argument.p:
how Lincoln's Message was received in Camp.
Affairs at Camp Walker, &c.

dateline.name: Camp Walker, Manassas Junction, Headqr's 5th Reg't S. C. V.,

div4.p:
Seward's pronunciamento, called Lincoln's Message, was received in our camp with a general feeling of contempt and indifference.
No one seemed to be surprised at its absurdity, nor alarmed at its sophistry.
It is just such a paper as might be expected to emanate from a fool's vanity and a fanatic's heart.
No honest, sensible man could ever have written such a mongrel of bravado, falsehood and presumption.
We are only afraid the abolition Congress won't be fool enough to sustain the Message, and attempt to raise the 400,000 troops and 4,000,000 dollars, because we believe such an attempt would expose the folly and vanity of Lincoln's ideas of government and war. If we are to judge the future by the past, 400,000 troops will not be more than one-fourth enough to furnish us a good fight, much less to conquer us; but I am not disposed to boast of what we can do. I only judge of what we have done.

Our camp is as quiet as usual.
The rains during the last few days have laid the dust and cooled the atmosphere, making our habitations comparatively comfortable.
Nothing worthy of note has transpired at Camp Walker since I last wrote you. The health of our regiment continues remarkably good.
We have been in service now three months and have lost only one man, and he died while the regiment, including our skilful surgeon, was at home on furlough for a few days previous to our departure for Virginia.
The success which has attended his practice among our sick is the best evidence of his skill and devotion to his business that could be produced, and in saying this of Dr. Thomson, I do not mean to deprive his accomplished assistant, Dr. Bratton, of that share of the honor to which his assiduous and faithful discharge of his duties so justly entitle him.

I see you do not mention Brig Gen.
Jones in the list of officers in the Confederate States service published yesterday, but we don't feel at all hurt at it, for we know that the will have "a place in the picture" whenever we are called into action, which will make him conspicuous enough.
I presume it was an oversight, for we will have no General in the field who will act better his part in the battle than our own Brigadier General, D. R. Jones.
Dan.

div3.head: Destructive fire
div3.p:
--Five Large Stores in Ruins.--About two o'clock this morning an alarm of fire was sounded, and flames were found to be issuing from the large brick tenement on the levee between Adams and Washington street, occupied by Mr. S. C. Barnett as a hotel.
The flames spread rapidly, and not withstanding the efforts of the firemen, they were not subdued till that and four other stores adjoining had been consumed.--The first tenement consumed — that in which the fire originated — was occupied, as before stated, by Mr. S. C. Barnett.
The house and furniture, all of which was lost, is estimated at $18,000. There was no insurance.

The adjoining tenement was owned by Wm Carr, and was used for storage, in which there was about $300 worth of goods.
The building was estimated to be worth $4,500. Insured for $2,500

The next three stores were large and valuable, and belonged to A. J. Walt, Esq. They were unoccupied, and used for storage purposes Some 700 barrels cement, 250 barrels lime, 200 sacks corn, 20 sets chairs, and a lot of hair, were stored in these stores, and was mostly consumed.
The tenements are estimated to be worth $10,000 each.
Mr. Walt had an insurance of $4,000 in the Magnolia, of Cincinnati, on one tenement; the others had been insured in home offices, but he does not yet know whether or not his policies have run out.-- Memphis Bulletin, 11th.

div3.head: A Legend of Norway.
div3.p:
--Near the village of Sand, in Norway, lived an old woman who was constantly rowing about in the Fiord in search of her husband, who had been drowned.
She rowed around the same circle, never deserting the spot, but whistling and chaunting by turns, her face turned in one direction, that she might watch the surface of the water.
One morning the poor fisherman plunged into the element that had been his sole sustaining friend from youth, to bathe, and before scarce fifteen minutes had elapsed, surrounded by a shoal of mackerel, and in sight of her who had made home pleasant, was devoured by these ravenous fish.

When he raised his arm out of the water to show the dreadful fate that threatened him, and arouse the alarm of his unconscious wife, a hundred mackerel hung like plummets from the flesh.
The fisherman sank, and was never seen or heard of more.
From that morning until to-day, his widow having lost her reason, ever rows her husband's boat about the spot where he perished, in full persuasion that he has gone to seek a sunken net, and in a little while will emerge again; and so she prays the crew of every vessel sailing by to stay and see the truth of what she relates.

div3.head: The gaps.
div3.p:
--A friend of ours, says the Nashville Gazette, tells us of an elderly lady friend of his who is thoroughly impressed with the idea that "Old Master is on our side." Her opinion, too, is based upon practical reason, as we infer from a remark she made to our friend.
"I know Providence is on our side," said she, "because not a single chicken in our neighborhood has had the gaps this summer." How is it possible for Lincoln to be such a miserable old fool as to hope for the subjugation of a people whose chickens stubbornly refuse to take the gaps in the summer time?

Messrs. D. S. Hounshell and A. Peery had a rencontre near Jeffersonville, Va., on the 7th inst.
Rocks and pistols were freely used, but nobody hurt.

div3.head:
The fight in Missouri.
Northern account.
div3.p: --We are indebted to the Kansas Journal for a copy of the Fort Scott Democrat of the 7th, containing an account of a battle between the Missouri State troops under Governor Jackson and General Rains, numbering, by their accounts, from ten to thirteen thousand, and the United States force under Col. Sigle, numbering one thousand five hundred in all. Our informant says that on Wednesday, the 3d inst., the State troops left Rupe's Point and moved South to Murray's six miles. On Friday morning, at 8 o'clock, they broke up camp and marched South in the direction of Carthage, the county-seat of Jackson county.--At Abbay Fork, seven miles North of Carthage, they were met by Colonel Sigel with fifteen hundred men, who immediately gave them battle.

The first onset resulted in the State troops being driven back some distance, and the officers ordered a retreat.
The centre gave way, but the order not being heard on the flanks, the advancing United States troops were in danger of being surrounded.
The flanks finally fell back, slowly keeping up the fight with their artillery, which made fearful havoc in the enemy's ranks.
At the crossing of Dry Fork our lines were very near being taken, when by the arrival of 200 Union men from Shoal Creek, they crossed with a loss of but five killed and two wounded.

The battle continued, the United States troops alternately fighting and retreating until dark, when they reached Carthage, having crossed Buck branch and Spring river.
On the way the fighting was all done with the artillery, Col. Sigel retreating as soon as they advanced.

It is believed that Col. Sigel's object was to draw the State troops on Carthage, when, with 400 reserve troops at that place, and expected reinforcements from Neosho and Sarcoxie, he would be enabled to turn and drive back or rout them.

The loss on Jackson's side was very great Our informant says he counted 70 or 80 wounded left on the field and in houses by the way side.
At Dry Fork a large amount of beef was thrown out of wagons, it is supposed to make room for the dead.

Another informant residing at Carthage states that he passed over a part of the battle-field yesterday morning, and saw wagons and hacks passing in every direction gathering up the dead for interment.
The loss on the part of the State troops cannot be less than from 300 to 500.
The ground in many places was strewn with dead horses, and the stench was sickening.
The whole country was laid desolate fences torn down, crops trampled into the ground, and houses plundered.
He met parties of women who stated that everything had been taken from them by the State troops except what they had on their backs.

The retreat was conducted in a style worthy of veteran troops, and with as much coolness as upon parade.
It was only the overwhelming odds on the side of the Secessionists that enabled them to carry the day. The victory was really with Sigel.

It was reported that a night attack had been made on Sigel, and 400 of his troops killed and 600 taken prisoners, with three pieces of artillery, but our informant says he overheard a messenger from the Secession camp say that they had killed only one man, after entering Carthage, and had taken no guns.

Jackson announces his intention of fortifying himself at Carthage until Price and McCulloch arrive from Arkansas with reinforcements, when he will act on the offensive and enforce the laws of the State.
Major Sigel retreated in the direction of Sarcoxie, where he expected reinforcements.-- Nothing can be heard from Major Sturgis or Gen. Lyon

Later.--July 7, 8 o'clock, P. M.--A citizen of this place has just arrived, having left Sherman, Jasper county, at daylight this morning.
He states that, after leaving Carthage, Col Sigel moved two miles southeast of the town, where he encamped for the night.
His command is badly cut up. His loss is variously estimated at from 300 to 1,000, and that of the Secessionists from 1,000 to 2,000 killed and wounded. Col. Brown, with 3,000 troops from Springfield, is said to have joined Col. Sigel.
Major Sturgis is north of the Osage, and Gen. Lyon, at last accounts, was at Warsaw, on his way South.

On Friday, the day of the battle, Ben. McCulloch and Gen. Price arrived at Neosho, 20 miles South of Carthage, with 10,000 men. A guard of 200 men left there by Sigel, was surrounded and taken prisoners.
One report says that all were murdered, and another that but a small portion of them were killed.
McCulloch sent forward 2,000 men to assist Jackson.
He expects 5,000 additional troops from Arkansas.

St. Louis, July 10--The Springfield correspondent of the Democrat, under date of the 6th inst., says, immediately after the arrival, Brig. Gen. Sweeny, at Springfield, dispatched messengers to Cols. Sigel and Solomon, who were encamped at Neosho, to move their columns to Carthage, which was promptly done.

Last night a messenger arrived from Col. Sigel, stating that Jackson and Gens. Price and Rains had united their forces, and were encamped eight miles North of Carthage.
Sigel and Solomon pushed forward rapidly and attacked the rebel force early yesterday morning, and continued fighting during the day.

Messengers are constantly bringing information that the rebels are retreating Southeastwardly between Sarcoxie and Mount Vernon, falling back on Caseyville with their baggage and plunder, under cover of their cannon, and Sigel attacking their rear.
This afternoon Gen. Sweeny commands in person a flying column, moving Southwardly to intercept the rebels at Vernon, thus crushing them completely between our columns.

Large bodies of mounted men are congregating at West Plains and Forsyth, with the intention of joining Jackson's force, but Sweeny sent a detachment of 200 mounted men through Douglas county, to prevent their union and drive back Gen. McBride's command.
A company of Home Guards arrived last night, bringing Col. Coffee, late member of the Legislature, as a prisoner.

Later advices say a report reached Springfield Sunday morning, of an engagement between 500 Federalists, under Col. Wolf, and 1500 rebels.
Wolf occupied a prairie when the battle began, but the rebels retreating to the woods he followed, and in skirmishing lost 30 men killed and wounded, he himself being among the killed.

The loss of the rebels was considerable, but not definitely ascertained.
A messenger was then dispatched to Springfield for reinforcements, and the whole force pushed forward.

Gen. Lyon was at Leesville, Cloud county, on Sunday morning Major Sturgis was at Clinton, Henry county, on the same day.--They expected to form a junction about ten miles south of Clinton on Sunday night.

div3.head: Affairs at Cairo.
div3.p:
--We continue our accounts of the condition of the Northern troops at Cairo.
This is from the Cairo correspondence of the Cincinnati Enquirer, dated July 8:

You may think it singular that after all the patriotic talk that so few take the three years oath.
It is simply this, they are disgusted with political officers who don't know as much about war as their privates.
The officers here, as a general thing, have little control over their men, as their acts in the bread and water riots will show.
They pay them no money, and talk pretty to them, until they swear in for three years, which the men are beginning to see.

Their vote will tell the tale.
Another thing is, they mix Lincolnism with patriotism.
They are not synonymous.
They should pay here.
The privates have no money.
Hundreds of them in and near Cairo get passed out of camp, and pick blackberries and sell them for tobacco.
They are not to be blamed for going in debt.
Even the officers cannot pay their hotel bills.

Wash women have told me that they were threatened to be turned out of house and home because they could not pay ten dollars board, and that Colonels in the army owed them over that amount for washing.
The soldiers boarding at the St. Charles Hotel owe that house over ten thousand dollars. They owe for board; they owe for whiskey, and every thing else.

Cairo is supposed to be in charge of the civil authorities, but in reality it is under martial law. A stranger or citizen cannot express an opinion unless the patrol, as they call the street (soldier) squad, will try to analyze it, and if not of their particular polities will arrest you.

Last night we saw a man arrested because he said he was a Kentuckian by adoption and had left Memphis because he feared they would draft him into the Southern army; but his father, mother, brothers and sisters lived in Kentucky, and he would go as Kentucky went.
The guard said they had orders to arrest all men that expressed such sentiments.
I could not learn the officer's name.
They were of Company A, Eighth Regiment.

div3.head: Revolutionary relics.
div3.p: --A correspondent of the Raleigh Register writes from Yorktown:

q.p:
In digging our trenches, we came across any amount of revolutionary relics, in the shape of old broken arms, cannon balls, pieces of shell, &c. The "Dixie Boys," the other day, came across several human skeletons, one of which was by itself; and the ball that killed him was lying among the bones.
Who knows but that in some future day, the traveler in passing over these fields may behold ten or a hundred, to where we see one now — there died in fighting the second war of independence.
But if blood must be the price of our liberty, 1st the price be paid freely.
Some look for an honorable peace soon, without much bloodshed — others do not; but we all want our rights, cost what they may.

div3.head: Still they go.
div3.p: --Volunteer companies from all parts of the State are continually passing through our city, bound for the seat of war. They are all a stout and brave looking set of fellows, and will do their duty when they most the enemy.--Montgomery Post.

div3.head:
"Government is in Danger."
[from the New York Daily News.]
div3.p:
Goldencalf, in Cooper's Mannikins, says to his son, "Government is in danger!
loans and regiments if thou wilt.
Give us more order; bayonets are what we want, boy, and good wholesome taxes, to accustom the nation to contribute to its own wants and sustain its credit."

This all sounds marvelously like the cry now abroad at the North.
From the President down to the Trays, Blanches and Sweethearts of the war journals, all bark to the same tune.
Government, it is true, is in danger; but like the cry of "stop thief," started by the thief himself, the danger is from the men who raise the cry. Who is it that, having obtained control or the Government, has violated every fundamental guarantee of the Constitution?
The war party.
Who is it that has placed the civil and political rights of our people at the pleasure of an unrestricted military power, subject to the arbitrary and anti-republican caprices of what is entitled "a military necessity?" The war President.
Who is it that has made the civil subordinate to the military power?
This same chief executive officer, who had solemnly sworn to preserve and defend that Constitution, whose provisions he has so ruthlessly trampled under foot.

Give us more order, too, is the cry; "bayonets are what we want, and good, wholesome taxes." "Order" once, we have understood, "reigned in Warsaw," and it was established there because the Russian artillery had destroyed its noble defenders, and silenced forever the voice of the patriots who fell fighting in defence of its liberties.
This is ever the kind of order that wails upon the bidding of bayonets.
It is the "order" tyrants seek for. It comes only at such bidding.
It is "order," but simply the regulation of arbitrary power.
It is the same order that now reigns in oppressed Baltimore, and in the State of which it is the chief city.
Maryland is still a State in this Union, faithful to all the obligations of that relation, and yet she is governed as a conquered enemy.
Her soil is occupied; her property and that of her citizens sequestered; her public highways seized and obstructed; her laws suspended, and her chief city converted into a military post.
Merciful Heavens!
How long is it to be before the people of the North will awake to the awful responsibilities of their position?

Depraved and hardened in falsehood and deceit was the brain that conceived and the hand that penned the President's recent message.
It is a tissue of misstatements, perversions of well known historical facts, illogical deductions, and impudent propositions from beginning to end. It is untrue that the original policy of Mr. Lincoln was "to exhaust peaceful measures before resorting to stronger ones." He declared the contrary in nearly every one of the speeches he delivered between Springfield and Harrisburg, and in his war proclamation he distinctly averred that his Inaugural Address meant war. It is untrue that "he only intended, originally, to hold the places not yet wrested from the Government." In his inaugural he openly threatened to retake "all property belonging to the United States," and, at Indianapolis and Cleveland, he proclaimed that to send an army into South Carolina "would not be invasion," and that to seize the fortresses in the hands of the seceding States would not be coercion.
The whole Fort Sumter story, as related by the President, is so infamously mendacious that no one acquainted with the real facts of the case, or who has read the statements of Judge Campbell and of the three Commissioners from Montgomery, can fail to pronounce the fabrications it contains more worthy of the denizen of a State prison, than of the head of an enlightened people.--Line by line, the sentences of the Presidential apology for endeavoring to re-enforce and provision Major Anderson, are so packed with deliberate untruths, that each syllable may be said to embody some separate falsehood of its own.

Mr. Lincoln passes from his Fort Sumter romance to the beginning of the war. He falsely states that "no choice was left but to call out the war power of the Government, and so to resist the force employed for its destruction by force for its preservation." No-choice left!
By the advice of his Abolition associates, he actually swindled the country into the fratricidal conflict which he so basely inaugurated.
Neither could he summon "out the war power of the Government," for outside of the twelve thousand men composing the Federal army such a "war power" did not exist, nor could it, without perjury, be created by him. Neither had any force been employed for the "destruction of the Government, " and consequently no "force for its preservation" was needed.
From so baseless and empty a preface, Mr. Lincoln goes on to justify his subsequent proceedings.
In the teeth of his pretended respect for authority, he recognizes the bogus Governor and Legislature of Western Virginia, and misstates the material facts connected with the action of that State.
He says that the call for three years volunteers was "ventured upon, whether legal or not, under what appeared to be a necessity, trusting then, as now, that Congress would ratify the same!" He then proceeds to justify the violation of the suspension of the writ of habeas corpus, with a detail of untruths with respect to the cause of that high-handed measure, which we shall take a future occasion to expose as they deserve.
With a wretchedness of special pleading seldom equaled, he endeavors to show that the framers of the Constitution intended to intrust the President with the power of setting the writ aside, although in the preceding paragraph he had virtually confessed that be had been guilty of a shameful usurpation in doing so.

In face of the fact that the relations of the U. States with foreign Powers are of the most precarious description, and that we are, perhaps, on the eve of a war with both Great Britain and France, and not impossibly Spain, Mr. Lincoln asserts that a "general sympathy is manifested with this country throughout the world." Nevertheless, he confesses that his own policy had led them to believe that the "early destruction of our National Union was probable." He then proceeds to the single paragraph which embodies all for which he really felt compelled to call Congress together, namely, to obtain money.
He wants, he says, "at least 400,000 men and $400,000,000 and presupposes a debt for the present year of no less than $600,000,000, which he flippantly tells us is really no amount at all, "a less sum per head than was the debt of our Revolution when we came out of that struggle; and surely, " he continues, "each man has as strong a motive now to preserve our liberties (!!) as each had then to establish them." What reckless sublimity of imposture!
"Our liberties" to be "preserved" by bankrupting the Republic, in order to enslave ten millions of our fellow-citizens, and reduce their territory to the condition of a wretched, subjugated province!

The remainder of the message is exclusively devoted to a miserable essay on State sovereignty, in which the exploded errors of Federalism are swamped in so silly, disconnected and slovenly manner, that even our most ferocious Republican contemporaries are ashamed and disgusted with the performance.
He interlards it with pusillanimous appeals, ad misericordiam, bad jokes and hypocritical buncombe for the benefit of the Beecher and Tying school of parsons, which are simply nauseous.
The only true statement this or any other portion of the document contains is, that not a single regiment has been sent South "out of which a President, Cabinet and Congress could not be selected," as good as those now in Washington.
No sensible man will dispute this.
Mr. Lincoln would have been nearer the truth had he declared that it would be impossible to choose from the very worst regiment, even in Missouri, a Chief Magistrate and Government more untruthful, dishonest and undeserving of public confidence.

div3.head: The Kanawha Valley.
div3.p: --A member of the Valley Rangers (Wise's Legion) writes to the Rockingham Register:

q.p:
We are encamped upon the lands which the "Father of his Country" donated from Congress, as a free gift for services rendered in the Revolution — lands selected by himself, and for a few short years subject to his orders.--Oh, how hallowed the recollection!
How soul-inspiring is the thought to know that we are now protecting the property which he received as a grand remuneration for his fatherly protection of the country at large.
Well might the eye of the great Chieftain encompass such a beautiful and fertile area as this — the most varied mountain scenery around on three sides, and the smooth Kanawha on the fourth.
It inspires the souls of us who now guard.
It inspires the souls of us who now guard the sacred land, with the sublime idea that the Chieftain's immortal spirit is e'en now hovering o'er us, shedding the Divine influence of his immortal greatness around our humble camp.

div3.head: Tent for Gen. Beauregard.
div3.p:
--A splendid tent, with a fine pole, the latter made of South Carolina cypress, both manufactured in Charleston, was sent as a present to General Beauregard, by some of our citizens, a few days since.
It is perhaps unnecessary for us to say that this small testimonial only expresses the universal confidence and respect which our people have for the soldierly and personal qualities of Gen. B.--Charleston Mercury.

div3.head: Personal.
div3.p:
--We had the pleasure of meeting in our city, on Tuesday evening, Major A. B. Reagan, formerly of Georgia, but for several years Commissary in the United States Army. Major Reagan has resigned his commission in the Old Wreck and is now on his way to Richmond.
We trust his valuable services may find suitable employment in our Confederacy.--Montgomery Mail.

div3.head: Felonious Homicide
div3.p:
--Andrew Tucker was confined in our jail yesterday for the murder of Miss Elizabeth Wintz, about three miles above this place, on Sunday evening, the 7th inst.
We understand he shot her with a pistol, and, fearing that would not kill her, cut her throat, after which he attempted to cut his own throat.--Kanawha Star.
St. John Moore, Esq., of Augusta, Ga., died on Tuesday last.
Randolph county, N. C., has subscribed $40,000 for war purposes.

div3.head: The News from Laurel Hill.
div3.p: --The following dispatch has been received here:

div4.p:
--To Mr. G. D. Prentice: Gen. McClellan has captured the entire camp of the enemy at Laurel Hill, with their guns, tents, and wagons, and many prisoners, among whom were several officers.
Their loss was very severe, while our's was very small.
No officers lost on our side.
A later dispatch from Cincinnati says:

cit.q:
--"Anderson's dispatch is not reliable.
He has got things mixed.
The camp at Laurel Hill has not been taken."

div4.p: [Gen. Garnett is in command at Laurel Hill, and it was at this point that the recent report originated of the capture, by a Georgia Regiment, of quite a number of Federal troops.]

div3.head: McClellan's column.
div3.p:
--General McClellan's Federal column is feeling its way cautiously.
The Southerners are daily being reinforced.
Since the approach of the Federal forces, the Southerners are working with great energy.
Gen. McClellan will probably make a demonstration this afternoon.

div3.head: From the Army in the Northwest.
div3.p: --Dispatches received here from St. Louis and Chicago are unfavorable to the patriots at Vernon, but Quincy (in the neighborhood of the battle field,) from which only reliable information has been obtained, is silent.
A dispatch dated at Roaring Run the Cincinnati Gazette, previous to the battle, says that the Federal forces were 10,000 strong.
Col. Pegram's command of Southerners only numbered 2,000.

div3.head: Another account.
div3.p:
--There was a battle on yesterday at the Rich Mountain.
The Southerners, numbering 2,000, under the command of Col. Pegram, surrendered.
The fight lasted one hour and a half.
The other part of the Southern force retreated, leaving sixty killed and many wounded, and numerous prisoners.
Six guns were taken and a number of horses.
The Federal loss was twenty killed, forty wounded, and many horses lost.

div3.head: The St. Louis State Journal.
div3.p:
--There is great excitement here in consequence of the reported order for the suppression of the State Journal, but no disturbance has yet occurred.
Five hundred troops are under arms in different parts of the city.

Later.--Four hundred troops, under the command of Col. McNeil, being his reserved guard, removed the type, paper and fixtures in the State Journal office.
The Colonel read an order from Gen. Lyon, prohibiting the further publication of the Journal.

div3.head: What Gen Scott learned from a negro.
div3.p:
--Gen. Scott has been in consultation with an Alabama negro, who says that there are five regiments and eighteen field pieces in and around Fairfax Court-House.
Among other information the negro informed Gen. Scott that everything indicated that the Southerners were about to retreat.

div3.head: The State of affairs in Missouri.
div3.p:
--The Missourians are gathering around Booneville, and the invaders are under arms every night, expecting an attack.
The same condition of things exists at Lexington.
Reinforcements, especially artillery, are greatly needed.

div3.head: Things in St Louis.
div3.p:
--The houses of Southern patriots were opened on Thursday night for rejoicing.
Though not illuminated, the city looked bright.
Dutch garden keepers and actors are not now so proud of their fellows, Zeigler and Boernstein.
A number of foreigners are reported to be leaving the city in fright.

div3.head: Confirmation of the Missouri News.
div3.p: --A special dispatch from Warsaw to the editor of the Republican, in this city, reiterates the statement of the total annihilation of Gen. Zeigler's command.

div3.head: The Northern Congress.
div3.p: --In the Senate, the bill providing for additional paymasters and the Force bill were passed.
In the house the Civil Appropriations bill and the bill authorizing the raising of $500,000 volunteers were passed.

div3.head: The privateer Jeff. Davis.
div3.p: --The bark Mary Goddell has arrived here, and reports that she was boarded by the privateer Jeff. Davis, which has captured several vessels within the past week.

div3.head: The "Jeff. Davis" again.
div3.p: --The schooner Enchantress, from Boston, has been captured by the privateer Jeff. Davis.

div3.head: More Captures.
div3.p: --An arrival here states that the privateer Jeff Davis has captured three prizes off Cape Hatteras.

div3.head: A want of money.
div3.p: --The want of money is the reason assigned for discharging the clerks in the Patent Office.

div3.head: The Ruffian Montgomery.
div3.p: --Montgomery's jayhawk bandits are reported to be devastating the Western borders of Missouri.

div3.head: The St. Nicholas affair.
div3.p: --Four men were arrested to-day who are implicated in the seizure of the St. Nicholas.

div3.head: An "Important" Dispatch.
div3.p: --The contract committee consists of Messrs. Van Wyck, Washburne, Holman, Fenton and Steele.

div3.head: Affairs at Louisville.
div3.p: --Judge Logan, who is the associate with Judge Murin in the Railroad case, publishes a dissenting opinion.

div3.head: Opposition to Lincoln.
div3.p: --Speeches and votes indicate that there are five Representatives and seven Senators who oppose the Administration.

div3.head: Arrest
div3.p: --Mr. Taliaferro, son-in-law to Senator Mason, has been arrested as a spy.

div3.head: A considerable Dwindle down.
div3.p: --The reserve of 80,000 has dwindled down to 3,000.

div3.head: New York cotton Market.
div3.p: --The sales of cotton to-day were 500 bales. Middlings 15½ cts.

div3.p:

He will be at his office generally from 8 to 9 o'clock A. M, and from 3 to 4 o'clock P. M. Invalids who wish to consult him, and are able to call at his office, will please do so during these hours.

div3.p:
--The subscriber will contribute the sum of $400 towards the equipment of any Volunteer Company in process of organization, provided a commission as Second Lieutenant can be secured in the Company for a friend who has had military experience, and who has been in active service since the secession of Virginia, or a, additional sum of $100 for a commission as First Lieutenant.
Address "military," cars Box 746, Petersburg, Va.

Greensboro' is a healthy, quiet, pleasant village, remote from the seat of war and the sea coast of the State, and is well defended by a Home Guard against any local disturbance.
Parents may place their daughters in this Institution with the assurance that they will be well instructed, and vigilantly protected from harm

At this season of the year it is very necessary that such a preparation should be in the hands of travellers and soldiers.
It is agreeable to the taste, and much preferable to Epsom Salts, Seidlitz Powders, and other purgatives.--For sale at Meade & Baker's Drug Store, 186 Main st, corner above Post-Office.

div3.head: The value of two Ringlets
div3.p: --A correspondent from Hamburg tells the following:

q.p:
I cannot close without giving you a rich piece of scandal in shopkeeping life that has been the town's amusement for same days.--Have you ever heard of a suit to recover the value of two ringlets?
If you have not you are behind us. The case is this: The pretty daughter of a poor merchant of this place honestly and finally aided her family with her earnings as a dress cutter and fitter, and in the pursuit of her occupation intently had to make small purchases in a shop situated in the old part of the city.
The shop in question rejoiced in the presence of a young and dishing clerk whose parents were in easy circumstances.

The clerk, guided by sentiments I will not undertake to analyze, had often begged our pretty dressmaker to give him one of her beautiful ringlets but Marguerita refused, as any clever Miss might very rightly do. However, one fine morning our enter prising friend, the clerk, carried his joke so far as to flourish a pair of scissors, as he very lamely said afterward by way of a joke, in rather too close proximity to the young mail den's bowing locks, and fate would have it that two very fine ringlets from among the number fell into his hand.

The father of the girl now appears upon the scene and claims the snug little sum of 1,500 silver marks for damages.
The clerk has tried to compromise by paying 400 marks, but to no purpose, and the Courts must now decide the value of this new Rape of the Lucks.

div3.head: Calico and Silk
div3.p:
--There are people, we know, who deep as called.
They ignore even a knowledge of its aspects and qualities — very good.
We have no wish to quarrel with their tests.
It is well for society that tastes differ; and that with the progress of luxury and means, that difference occasions desires that fill our stores with gay robes, shawls, mantillas, etc., increase the exertions of trade, add an impetus to commercial enterprise, and so swell the national wealth.
But apart from all these considerations, why should not a modest woman look as well in calico as in silk?
Is there not as much real beauty, artistically speaking in a form clad gracefully in one article, as a form no more gracefully clad, in another?

There are women, no doubt, so much controlled by the mere dicta of fashion, and they despise common sense.
They admire nothing but what is costly.
They prefer ancient elegance to anything new, which does not go beyond a good taste, and a durable substance — Tis "a foolish and a vain pretence," and adds nothing to a sensible lady's credit for sound judgment.
In truth, it makes little difference what material a woman wears, so it suits the time and her own social position.
Be it call color silk, it is the woman that adorns the dress — not the dress the women.

div3.head: Making Virginia.
div3.p:
--To eight gallons of clear rain water add three quarts of molasses; put into a good cask; shake well a few times, then add two or three spoonfuls of good yeast cakes.
It in summer, place the cask in the sun; if in winter, near the chimney, where it may worm.
In ten or fifteen days add to this liquid a sheet of brown paper, torn in strips, dipped in molasses, and good vinegar will be produced.
The paper will in this way, form what is called the "mother," or life of vinegar.

My deceased uncle, says a humorous writer, was the most polite gentleman in the world.
He was making a voyage on the Danube, and the boat sunk: all the passengers went to the bottom.
My uncle was just at the point of drowning.
He got high all above the water for once, took off his hat, and said: "Ladies and gentleman, you must please excuse me!" and down he went.

div3.head: Hospital of the Medical College of Virginia.
div3.p:
--This Hospital erected by the liberally of the State, at a cost of morthan $20,000, is now completed, and open for the reception of patients.
It is admirably adapted by its plan for the accommodation of the sick, and to furnished with every convenience requisite for their comfort and successful treatment.
Its alternation, on Marshall street, cast of 12th, immediately adjacent to the Medical College, while retired and airy, is at the same time central, and convenient of access from all parts of the city.
The patients are under the immediate charge or the Professors of the College, (who make daily visits,) assisted by a competent Resident Physician.
All persons requiring Medical or Surgical treatment are admitted, except the Insane, and those laboring under Small — Pox and other infections disorders.
Lying — in Women, both white and colored, receive special care and attention.

row.cell: Including Board, Medical Attendance, &c. While patients

For Surgical operations, a fee ranging from to $40 will be required, in addition to the above weekly rates.

an Ordinance Prohibiting THESALE of Liquor on Sunday, Passed July 8 1861:

This Ordinance shall be in force from its passage.

for the purpose of conducting the Produce Commission business, and will give especial attention to the sale of Tobacco.

Claiborne Barksdale,
Richmond, July 1, 1861.

A Card.--I have this day sold out my entires interest in the concern of Barksdale & Brothers to my two brothers, Claiborne and Charles H. Barksdale who will continue the Commission business under the style and firm of Barksdale & Brother, and will occupy the some office formerly occupied by the firm of Barksdale & Brothers.
Mr. J. H. Harris will be retained as Clerk by the new concern.
All persons having claims against, of indebted to the firm of Barksdale &Brothers, will present their claims to the new concern of Barksdale & Brother for settlement.
I shall continue to act as chief Salesman of Tobacco for the firm of Barksdale & Brother, and cordially recommend my two brothers, Claiborne and Charles H. Barksdale, to the patronage of my old customers and the public generally Clem't. R. Barksdale

Greensborough, N, C
div3.p: This Institution has been in successful operation for twenty-one years, and for the last ten years under its present Principal.
The course of instruction is designed to afford to Southern parents an institution in which can be secured every advantage afforded by the very best Female Seminaries in the country

The Faculty consists of five gentlemen and four ladies.
The Institution is, and has been thoroughly Southern in its organization.
Greensborough is eminently healthy, and, it the present excited state of the country, its geographical position renders it a quiet and safe retreat.
The next session will commence August 1st, 1861.

div3.head: Headq'rs Maryland Volunteers
div3.p: Having been assigned by his Excellency the Governor of the State, and Advisory Council, to the command, for the present, of such volunteers from Maryland as may offer their services, the undersigned advises immediate organisation into companies of not less than fifty men, who will elect their own officers.
The certificates of election will be returned to the commanding officer, who will forthwith procure the proper commissions.
Each company will consist of one Captain, one First and one Second Lieutenant, four Sergeants, four Corporals, and at least forty — two privates.

It is earnestly recommended to the Maryland men that they lose no time in perfecting their organisation.
Inheriting as we do the name of the old "Maryland Line." let us imitate their virtues, and let the Maryland Line of to-day, as lid the grand "Old Maryland Continentale" of 1776, set an example of loyalty, discipline and courage to be emulated but not surpassed by our brothers of the South.
Francis J. Thomas,
my 23--ts Col. Commanding

div3.head: Executive Department,
div3.p: the Duties Involved in Supplying the troops in the field with Small Arms, Field Artillery, and Ammunition therefore, requiring a division of labor, the following order is issued:
The Colonel of Ordnance of Virginia will continue to attend to the issue of arms, both Artillery and Small Arms, belonging to this State, and to the manufacture of Field Carriages and Caissons.

The making up of all kinds of ammunition, including the manufacture of Percussion Caps and he issuing of the same, will be attended to by the Ordnance Department of the Southern Confederacy, for which purpose so much of the Ammunition as is now on hand at the Armory, and the present accommodation for further manufacture of Ammunition as is now appropriated for that purpose by this State, be turned over to the Confederate authorities during the continuance of he war.
The Colonel of Ordnance of Virginia will make the necessary arrangements to carry out the foregoing order John Letcher.

div3.head:
Virginia Hotel,
Staunton,
Virginia.
div3.p:
The Virginia Hotel, so extensively known to the traveling public as one of the very best Hotels in the State, is now owned solely by Messrs Wm.
H. & Thos. P. Peyton, who will devote their whole attention to the purpose of increasing if possible, the high reputation which it at present sustains, and will leave no exertion unemployed to render their guests satisfied and comfortable.
The recent additions put to this establishment enable the proprietors to accommodate a much larger number of guests than formerly.--The whole building, in the interior and exterior, has been recently Refitted and Painted and looks now good as New.

The proprietors have secured the services of Mr. Wm. D. Gilkeson, Sr., an experienced landlord, and formerly of the Taylor Hotel, Winchester, as Superintendent, who will pay every attention to those stopping at the Hotel.--Capable and faithful servants are also provided to ensure the comfort of guests.
The table will continue, as heretofore, to equal that of any hotel in the State.

Connected with the Hotel are extensive Stables, under the management of Byers & Co. well known for their experience and efficiency in this department.
Horses will be taken on livery and Horses, Buggies, and Hacks will be afforded to guests on reasonable terms.
The Proprietors are well prepared to accommodate families who wish to spend the Summer months in this healthy portion of the State.
This Hotel is well furnished, and contains as good and comfortable bedding as any house in the State.

In this Hotel there are two of Fielding's new and excellent marble-bedded, and patent-cushioned Billiard Tables.
New and comfortable Bathing Rooms have just been neatly fitted up

Wm. Peyton, who has been so long connected with this Hotel, will devote his whole attention to the accommodation of the guests.
He is thankful for the liberal patronage heretofore bestowed, and would respectfully ask a continuance of the same.
Wm. H. Peyton Proprietors.
Thos. P. Peyton, Proprietors.

N. B.--The office of all the Stage Lines is at this House; also, the office of Adams & Co's Express.
Wh. H. Peyton & Bro.
Staunton, March 15, 1861 ap 17--tf

div3.head: Variety Springs.
div3.p:

These Springs are situated 5 miles west of Staunton on the Virginia Central Railroad; cars stopping at the door.

the Proprietors will use every effort to give satisfaction to those who may visit this agreeable resort.

div3.head:
Warm Springs,
Bath county, Va.
div3.p: This famous and popular Watering place, the longest known Warm Bath in the country — and the only warm Sulphur Bath in the Union as it was or as it is — is now open for visitors.

The Bath is wonderfully efficacious in a great variety of diseases — among them Rheumatism.
Neuralgia, Gout, Dyspepsia, Liver Complaint, Chronic Diarrhœa, Paralysis, Diseases of the Kidneys, Nervous Affections etc.

The fine bracing atmosphere of the locality, and mountain scenery are great aids to the healing virtues of the waters.
Every attention is paid to guests.
and everything done to promote the comfort of the sick and well.
The Table is supplied with the best that can be obtained, including good venison almost every day.

The Warm Springs is within one day's journey from the principal cities of Virginia, Washington and Baltimore — only 15 miles west of Millborough on the Virginia Central Railroad.
A daily line from Millborough passes by the Springs on their way to the White Sulphur.
Terms reasonable to families by the month or season [jy 2--1m] Geo. Mayse.

div3.head: Ashland Hotel.
div3.p: This pleasant Summer Retreat is now open for the reception of visitors.

Ashland offers many attractions to all whom business of pleasure calls to the Capital of the Confederacy.
It is situated on the Richmond &Fredericksburg Railroad, within 45 minutes run of Richmond.
The trains pass down and up, so as to arrive at Richmond before, and at Ashland after, business hours.

The improvements consist of a spacious Hotel and sundry airy and tasteful Cottages, located in extensive and well shaded lawns The Cottages afford to families all the quiet and seclusion of private establishments in the country, freed fire the cares of housekeeping.
Indeed, all the comforts and advantages of the country are secured with ready access to the city, free of charge on the cars, to boarders at the Hotel.
Applications for board may be addressed to
Thomas B. P. Ingram,
jy 3--1m Superintendent.

div3.head:
Coyner's White
and Black Sulphur and
Malybeate Springs.
div3.p: This Watering-place will be open for the reception of visitors on the 30TH of may, It is situated on the line and in full view of the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad, about half a mile from Bonsack's Depot, Roanoke, Va., at which depot an Omnibus will always be found waiting in the arrival of the cars, to convey passengers to the Springs.

These White and Black Sulphur Waters have effected numerous cures.
The White Sulphur aggravated cases of dyspepsia, serious affection of the liver, kidneys, and bladder, general debility, and especially diseases of the nervous system, and those diseases peculiar to females.
The Black Sulphur, all kinds of diseases of the skin aggravated cases of tetter, and other corruption of the skin.

The accommodations are equal to any to be found in the mountains of Virginia, and the Table and Attendants of the most satisfactory character together with a fine Band of Music, and every attraction usually found at first-class Watering Places — as to all of which we beg leave to refer to the large number of persons who have heretofore visited the place.
Board will be reduced to $20 per month for families; children and servants half price.
There is also a Telegraph Office here which communicates with all parts of the South
J. A. Heffelfinger,
my 22--2m Proprietor

div3.head:
Montgomery
White Sulphur Springs,
in Montgomery county, Va.,
div3.p:
This delightful Watering Place was opened for the reception of visitors on the 20th day of May These Springs are more easy of access than any in Virginia, being immediately on the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad, in the most healthy portion of the State, and surrounded by the most beautiful mountain scenery.
The medicinal qualities of the waters are fully established, having been instrumental in the cure of many diseases peculiar to the Southern country.
This is not only a delightful summer resort, but, in these exciting times, a safe retreat for ladies and children.
Telegraph communication with all important points in the Confederate States.
A full supply of Ice on hand.
Louis F. J. Amiss, Proprietor.

James R Kent, President.
je 25--1m

Richmond & Danville Railroad,

div3.p: for the South and Southwest.
Richmond and Danville Railroad.
On and after Monday, July 16th, the Passenger Trains will run as follows:
going West.

Mail Train leaves Richmond Daily, (Sundays Included.) at 7 4 M: but on Sunday, the Train goes to Burkeville only, connecting there with the trains on the South-Side Railroad for the South and Southwest.
Mail Train leaves Danville Daily, (except Sundays,) at 6.07 A.M., and reaches Richmond at 1.55 P.M.
On Sundays there will be a Mail Train from Burkeville to Richmond, leaving Burkeville on the arrival of the Train from the South and Southwest at 10.55 A. M., and reaching Richmond at 1.55 P. M.
Trains from Richmond connect at Burkeville with the Trains on the South-side Railroad for Lynchburg and the South, and Southwest daily.
The Train from Danville connects at Burkeville with South-Side Railroad Trains for Petersburg and Norfolk

div3.head: Notice to Travelers
div3.p:
--Passengers leaving Richmond or Petersburg in the Afternoon, will not make A Continuous Connection South of Wilmington.
In consequence of the present temporary arrangement of schedule from Richmond South, by this train, passengers will lay over in Wilmington from 7 A. M. until 7 P. M.

By leaving Richmond or Petersburg in the morning, there will be a continuous connection all the way through.
S. L. Fremont.

div3.head: Office R. & P. Railroad Co.,
div3.p: this Company is prepared to issue the bonds referred to in the annexed resolution, in exchange for the Coupon Bonds now outstanding:

"Resolved, That the President and Treasurer of this Company be authorized to issue Registered Bonds in lieu of the Coupon Bonds of this Company now outstanding, to such persons as may desire to make such exchange; and it is hereby expressly understood and agreed that the Registered Bonds so issued shall be secured by any lieu heretofore given to secure the said Coupon Bonds, and that such lieu shall not be in any manner affected or impaired by such exchange of bonds.
It shall be the duty of the Board to have the Coupon Bonds, so received in exchange, cancelled, at or before the term of issuing the said Registered Bonds." M. W. Yarrington,
jy 4--1m Treasurer

div3.head: Office Richmond and P. R. R. Co.,
div3.p: through Freight arrangements to Charleston and Savannah, can be made at cheap rates, freight to be paid at either end of the line, by applying at this office Thos H. Wynne, Sup't

div3.head: $40 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway, some time in June last, my negro men, Sam and Washington They were seen with some of the Volunteer companies, going in the direction from Richmond to Yorktown.--Washington is suite black, at out five feet six inches high, and about twenty-five years old. Sam is a bright mulatto, about the same age and height.
I will give $20 for the delivery of either, or $4 for the delivery of both of said Negroes to Jas. M. Taylor & Son, at Richmond, or secured in any jail in the State so that I can get them
jy 1--5t R. N. J. Williamson

div3.head: Ranaway.
div3.p:
--From B brick yard in Manchester, on the 26th of June, a negro Boy, about twenty years old.--Said Boy is black, very stout built, and is about five feet high.
He is in Richmond-- has been seen frequently on the street.
His name to Jack Simra. I will give $10 reward for his delivery to me. B. J. Eddins.

div3.head: Runaway negro.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the service of the Virginia & Tennessee Railroad Company, in June last, a slave named Abraham.
He is about 35 years of age, 6 feet high, and of a dark brown color, Usually wears a hand kerchief on his head, and has a scar on his forehead or face.

Abraham belongs to Capt. John Buford, of Bed ford county, and it is supposed that he is now about Richmond, or at one of the volunteer encampments.
A liberal reward will be paid for him. E. H. Gill,
Gen't Sup't Va. & Tenn, Railroad.
Lynchburg, July 10, 1861. jy 10--1m
